speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about when the wrist pain started, was it sudden or did it come on gradually?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about three months ago, to be honest, I couldn't pinpoint exactly when it began. I just remember it started a bit after my baby was born, maybe because I was holding him a lot more and lifting him up. At first, I thought it was just from being a new mom and doing too much."

speaker: Doctor
text: "When did the pain become unbearable?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been getting worse over the past month or so, to be honest. I'd say it's been a 7 or 8 out of 10 in terms of pain level, and it's not just the pain itself, but also the stiffness and limited mobility I'm experiencing."

speaker: Doctor
text: "When did you first notice any weakness or numbness in your hand, if at all?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I haven't really noticed anything like that. My hand feels a bit weak, I suppose, when I try to hold my baby for an extended period or do activities that require a lot of grip strength, like changing diapers. But other than that, I haven't noticed any unusual sensations."

speaker: Doctor
text: "When you say the pain became unbearable, did that happen suddenly or did it take some time, like a few days or a few weeks?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It definitely wasn't sudden, I don't think. I mean, the pain was manageable at first, and I could still do all the things I needed to do, like caring for my baby and keeping up with my daily routine. But over the past month, it's just gotten to the point where I have to be more careful about how I'm lifting and moving, or it becomes really painful."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities - do you perform any tasks that involve repetitive hand movements, such as typing or using tools?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, I do a lot of typing on my laptop and phone, which can be a bit painful at times. And when I'm caring for my baby, I have to change diapers, feed him, and bathe him, which all involve some level of gripping and lifting. I've also been doing a lot of laundry and cooking, which can be tiring on my hands. I'm trying to be more mindful of my activities and take regular breaks to rest my hands."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'd like to take a look at the wrist and hand to assess for any deformities or swelling. Can you please extend your arm and I'll examine the wrist and hand for any abnormalities?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll do that. I'll just hold out my arm for you. And don't mind me if I look a bit awkward, my baby is always trying to grab at my arm or leg when I'm trying to move around."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you show me exactly where you're feeling the pain, is it a sharp ache or more of a dull ache, and is it constant or does it come and go?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more of a dull ache, to be honest. It's hard to describe, but it's like a constant hum of pain that's always there, but not always noticeable. I can feel it more when I'm using my hand or wrist for a task, or when I'm holding my baby and trying to lift him up."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your occupation or daily activities that involve lifting, bending, or any heavy lifting, which might have put additional stress on your wrist?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I work from home as a freelance writer, so I don't really have a traditional 9-to-5 job that involves heavy lifting or repetitive tasks. But I do have to lift and carry my laptop and other work materials around the house, and I've also been doing a lot of gardening lately, which involves bending and lifting tools. I try to pace myself and take breaks when I need to, but I'm sure that's not ideal for my wrist."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your work or daily activities that involve any twisting or bending of the wrist, such as using a computer mouse or handling objects with force?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, I do a lot of computer work, so I'm constantly using my wrist to move the mouse and type on my keyboard. And when I'm handling my baby, I have to twist my wrist to pick him up or to change his diaper, so I'm doing a lot of that twisting motion. I'm not sure if that's contributing to my wrist pain, but it's definitely something I'm aware of now."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about your job and whether you've had any recent changes or new equipment that might be contributing to the wrist pain?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I actually started working from home about six months ago, after taking a few months off to care for my baby. I've been doing freelance writing and it's been going well, but I did switch to a new laptop and keyboard a few months ago, and I've been using a different mouse that's a bit different from the one I used at my old job. I'm not sure if that's the cause of the pain, but I did notice that my hands and wrists were a bit sore after using the new equipment for the first few days."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your job and whether you've had any recent changes or new equipment that might be contributing to the wrist pain?



Also, I'd like to take a closer look at your hand movement. Can you slowly make a fist and then open it, and also move your wrist from side to side to see if there's any stiffness or discomfort?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll do that. Let me just make a fist... (pauses) And then open it. (opens hand) Okay, and then I'll move my wrist from side to side. (moves wrist) Hmm, I don't really feel any stiffness or discomfort, but it does feel a bit tight when I'm doing the twisting motion. Maybe that's just from getting used to holding my baby all the time?"

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about any activities you do that involve using your hands to grip or hold things tightly, such as holding a small object or using a tool with force?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, I do a lot of gripping and holding when I'm caring for my baby, like holding his bottle or pacifier, and when I'm doing laundry, I have to hold the washing machine and dryer handles tightly. And sometimes, I'll hold my baby's arms or legs to help him learn to crawl or stand. It's just something I've gotten used to doing, but I guess it could be contributing to the pain somehow."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'd like to request a test to see if there's any evidence of inflammation or infection in the wrist joint. Can you please have an X-ray of the wrist taken, please?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll go ahead and schedule that for you. I'm not really sure what to expect, but I trust your expertise. Will the X-ray hurt, or is it just a quick procedure?"

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Thank you for that information. I'd like to examine your wrist and hand again, this time focusing on the tendons and ligaments. Can you please hold out your hand and I'll gently press on the top of your wrist to assess for any tenderness?"

Can you please make a fist and hold it for a few seconds, then release? I'm also going to request a test to check for any fluid buildup or swelling in the wrist joint. REQUEST TEST: Wrist_Fluid_Test

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your sleep quality and whether you've noticed any pain or stiffness in your wrist or hand at night, and have you had any trouble falling asleep or staying asleep due to the wrist pain?



Also, while you're holding out your hand, I'd like to gently press on the top of your wrist again to see if the tenderness is still present, and I'll also assess for any pain when I apply gentle pressure to the back of your wrist.

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, I've actually noticed that the pain is pretty much constant, even at night. I'll wake up in the middle of the night and it's still there, just a dull ache. I've tried to get comfortable and move around, but it's just something I'm used to now. I don't really think it's affecting my sleep quality too much, but it's definitely something I'm aware of."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep quality and whether you've noticed any pain or stiffness in your wrist or hand at night, and have you had any trouble falling asleep or staying asleep due to the wrist pain?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'd say my sleep quality has been okay, I mean, I've been getting some rest and I don't really wake up in the middle of the night with a lot of pain. But I do have to admit, when I'm lying on my side, I can feel the pain a bit more, especially when my wrist is bent. I'm not sure if it's the position or what, but it's definitely something I'm aware of now."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep quality and whether you've noticed any pain or stiffness in your wrist or hand at night, and have you had any trouble falling asleep or staying asleep due to the wrist pain?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been okay, to be honest, I mean, I've been getting some rest and I don't really wake up in the middle of the night with a lot of pain. But I do have to admit, when I'm lying on my side, I can feel the pain a bit more, especially when my wrist is bent. I'm not sure if it's the position or what, but it's definitely something I'm aware of now. I've tried to sleep on my back and it seems to be a bit better, but I'm not sure if that's just a coincidence or if there's something else going on."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep quality and whether you've noticed any pain or stiffness in your wrist or hand at night, and have you had any trouble falling asleep or staying asleep due to the wrist pain?

speaker: Patient
text: "I think I've been managing to get a good amount of sleep, considering the pain I'm experiencing. I mean, it's not like I'm waking up in the middle of the night screaming or anything, but it's definitely something I'm aware of, and it's definitely not helping me get a good night's rest. I've tried to sleep on my back, as I mentioned, and it seems to be a bit better, but I'm not sure if that's just because I'm not putting pressure on my wrist or if there's actually something else going on."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I think I've gathered enough information. Let me review it one last time. I'll need to request one final test to confirm my diagnosis.
